intro: Mcvaughia sergipana, commonly known as the Sergipe morning glory, is a flowering plant native to Brazil. It belongs to the family Convolvulaceae and is characterized by its climbing habit and showy, trumpet-shaped flowers. The plant typically has heart-shaped leaves and produces vibrant, often purple or blue, blooms. It thrives in warm, humid climates and is often found in forested areas. Due to its ornamental value, it is cultivated in gardens and greenhouses in tropical regions.
